Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Cultural Competency for Disaster Risk Reduction and Recovery

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participant costs for a workshop and panel of anthropologists and anthropologically-informed humanitarian aid practitioners at the United Nations Global Platform for Disaster Risk Reduction in Cancun, Mexico, May 22-26, 2017. After a half-century of research on the human impacts of disasters, anthropologists know that it is necessary to take local cultures into account to reduce post-disaster suffering and speed recovery for disaster-affected communities. However, these well-documented findings are almost never implemented in disaster planning. Therefore, this workshop convenes a group of anthropologists and anthropology-minded practitioners to communicate anthropological disaster science findings directly to international policy makers concerned with disaster response and recovery. At the same time, by investigating the contexts of disaster policy-making itself, the workshop provides the anthropologists an opportunity to learn from the policy makers why local culture is consistently omitted from disaster planning.

Convened by the American Anthropological Association, the workshop brings together for the first-time practitioners, researchers, and academics whose work spans the fields of cultural anthropology, risk perception and communication, disaster risk reduction, recovery management, post-disaster needs assessment, reconstruction, and resettlement. Drawing on extensive fieldwork to theorize the persistent issues surrounding the role of culture in disaster policy and practice, workshop participants will share: (a) lessons learned from past disaster cases; (b) knowledge about best practices; and (c) action steps to advance the recognition and inclusion of cultural priorities and values among groups vulnerable to or impacted by disaster. These action steps will include strategies for how to adaptive capacity in contexts of disaster risk reduction and recovery planning. Additionally, the team will conduct a rapid ethnography of the UN Global Platform and the reactions to anthropological theory and application and work collaboratively to conduct a thematic analysis of documents and public statements produced as part of the Global Platform. Outcomes of will include: a roundtable presentation at the annual meetings of the American Anthropological Association; publication of a report in Anthropology News and in Natural Hazards Observer that identifies key themes and opportunities that emerge from the workshop; a paper that summarizes key themes of disaster anthropology and the implementation of cultural competency, and which critically assesses their potentiality within other disaster and risk reduction policy arenas; and the development of a policy brief outlining the role of cultural competency in risk reduction and disaster response.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This workshop grant supported direct participant costs for a workshop and panel (“Ignite Stage” presentation) of anthropologists and anthropologically-informed practitioners in humanitarian aid at the United Nations Global Platform for Disaster Risk Reduction in Cancun, May 22-26, 2017. Our workshop team included a total of seven professionals who have worked in diverse contexts with institutions such as UNDP, UNISDR, USAID, UNICEF, UNESCO, Samaritan’s Purse, The World Bank, the US Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), countless federal and local agencies, and universities in more than a dozen countries. The two principal goals of the project—both of which were met or exceeded—were to:

  • Produce an “Ignite Stage” Presentation (and accompanying information sheet) to present anthropological approaches to disaster risk reduction, response, and recovery to practitioners and policy-makers attending the Global Platform. The objectives were to share: (a) lessons learned; (b) knowledge about best practices; and (c) action steps to advance the recognition and inclusion of cultural priorities and values among groups vulnerable to or impacted by disaster.
  • Conduct a rapid ethnography of the Global Platform to study the production and circulation of the culture concept in the large international disaster planning community. Objectives were to attend and document formal sessions in the Global Platform and to interview professionals and leaders from a cross-section of governmental and nongovernmental organizations from around the world. 42 interviews with leaders and representatives of 36 governmental and nongovernmental organizations, covering more than 22 countries. Interviews asked respondents to explain what is meant by “culture,” how they and their organizations operationalize the concept in their policies and practices, and how the culture concept aligns with or diverges from key points (e.g., “build back better”) outlined in the UNISDR Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction.

Intellectual Merit

Our interviews and collective observations constituted a rapid ethnography of the disaster response community and their ideas and operationalizations of the culture concept, which in other contexts might be sidelined. It is important to note that anthropologists working with and within disaster response institutions often work alone. This is the first time a critical mass of anthropologists working on these issues directly engaged the disaster risk reduction community as a collective. Analysis is still ongoing, but we have begun to report preliminary findings in a number of outlets. Currently, the most salient results are that: (a) practitioner’s notions of culture and how best to work with communities are not always reflected in the policies and practices of their organizations, and vice versa; (b) many practitioners are very candid about their successes and failure in engaging local communities in culturally sensitive ways; (c) practitioners are often most aware of the successes and failures of disaster risk reduction/response/recovery operations; (d) they frequently share and contrast their experiences with one another in an effort to collectively benefit from “communities of practice”; and (e) while express definitions of culture and culturally-sensitive operational guidelines are often reductive, many practitioners emphasize the importance of working in active collaboration with locals for both the design and implementation of disaster risk reduction programs. As reported in the Annual-Final Report, we have several publications in public-facing outlets, several academic publications in prep, and several conference presentations and roundtables.

Broader Impacts

Our dissemination of results has included creating materials that can be used by practitioners in disaster prevention, response, and recovery. Our team produced a 15-minute Ignite Stage presentation that was part of the Global Platform program on Friday, May 26, 2017. A youtube video of the presentation (led by workshop participants Kate Browne and Adam Koons) can be seen here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=5&v=4_QfwY_iQak. Our “Culture in Disaster” Handout from Ignite Stage Talk and now featured on the Culture and Disaster Action Network (CADAN) website: http://cultureanddisaster.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/DDR_Cultur_Handout.pdf. We have continued communicating with interview participants and are working to create further workshops with them and other practitioners.

NSF funding supported the direct participant costs of a San Jose State University Anthropology graduate student from a demographic historically underrepresented in academia. This graduate student not only participated in the fieldwork and data collection, but also in analysis, and has continued to develop a thesis on discourses of disaster root causes in disaster risk reduction and recovery policy and practice. Additionally, the Department of Anthropology at San Jose State University supported this project by funding two research assistants from demographics historically underrepresented in academia.
